## Historical Context of Anna Karenina (1870s Russia)

### Railway Modernization and Industrial Development

During the 1870s, while Tolstoy was writing Anna Karenina, Russia was undergoing a great deal of political and societal change. Anna Karenina takes place against the backdrop of liberal reforms introduced by Emperor Alexander II in the 1860s. These reforms included rapid growth of industry, building of railroads, introduction of local government in the form of the zemstvo, military reforms, and a freer press.(no content)Railways became a significant topic of discussion among landowners and were emblematic of social disparities. The rise of fresh industries was perceived as not only accentuating the stark disparity between affluent industrialists and the impoverished peasantry, but also as a transfer of authority from the landed aristocracy to the industrialists.(no content)The country was caught between the relics of the past, traditions and inequalities which had continued unchanged for hundreds of years, and the impact of modernisation. The railways, which play such an important part in the book, open up the vast country; Vronsky's country estate is full of English goods and inventions, a sign of modernity and progress.

### Social Transformation and Class Structure

The wider setting puts these families into a historical context: Russia during the 1870s, about a dozen years after the abolition of serfdom.(no content)In 1861, just a decade before the novel is set, there took place the emancipation of the serfs in Russia. This made huge changes to the land and to the free movement of the peasants. It coincided with the beginning of industrial development in Russia.(no content)Throughout the novel, there is a growing tension between the old, patriarchal aristocracy and the rise of a new, freethinking middle class. There is a great deal of tension in the countryside between modernity and tradition.

### Women's Role in Society

When Tolstoy began to write Anna Karenina in the early 1870s, such social codes were already seen in some quarters as powerful impositions upon women's independence.(no content)One of the overriding themes in Anna Karenina is the role of women in Russian society. Women are generally depicted in traditional roles - wife and mother – which were de rigueur at the time.(no content)Women's rights fall under particular scrutiny, both by the characters themselves and by the readers as they watch these debates unfold.(no content)These contemporary developments included changes in a woman's role in society.

### Aristocratic Society and Its Decline

In Anna Karenina, Tolstoy also exposes what he saw as the artifice and vanity of 19th century Russian aristocratic society. The urban world is full of scandal and deception, gossip and rumor. Events in the city are treated on the basis of their societal repercussions.(no content)The landed aristocracy is decaying, and a new, rich, bourgeois middle class is taking its place.(no content)The aristocracy, a part of the political system, and the one with power at the time is feeling some anxiety on how long their ascendancy will last. They see Russia falling behind on the world stage and want to prevent this from happening.

### Transportation and Social Interaction

During the course of railway journeys, 1st class passengers might visit the 2nd class, while 2nd class (the gentry's staff) might visit the 1st class. From Petersburg to Moscow, mothers engage in discussions regarding their sons, whereas landowners talk about politics and the new railways.

The railway stations and trains themselves became important social spaces where different classes interacted and where significant plot developments occurred, including Anna's fateful first meeting with Vronsky and her eventual tragic end.

This historical context shows how Tolstoy captured a pivotal moment in Russian history when traditional aristocratic society was being challenged by modernization, industrialization, and changing social norms, particularly regarding women's roles and class structures.
